Award.AwardTitle: The Pamir Frontal Thrust System: Rates, Style, and Controls on Deformation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on the structural corridor that lies at the interface between the Pamirs and the Tian Shan in westernmost China. These two, oppositely facing orogens are progressively impinging on each other, and between them, have trapped the largest river in the region, the Kezilesu. Across a spatially compact zone, a diverse array of structures and contrasting deformation mechanisms accommodate rapid convergence, including low-angle thrust faults, reverse faults, fold scarps, folds, and flexural slip faults. Representing the leading edge of the Pamir orogenic wedge, the Pamir Frontal Thrust system is in places immediately adjacent to the Kezilesu River and at others the primary fault lies many kilometers from the river. This along-strike variability provides an opportunity to assess the concept that efficient fluvial erosion can focus deformation. Faster deformation rates farther from the axial river would tend to negate the erosion-deformation hypothesis. Accelerated rates on structures across the southern margin of the Tian Shan that are proximal to the Kezilesu compared to more distal sites would support the erosion-deformation hypothesis. To determine deformation rates, the research team will: delineate regional patterns of deformation at decadal time scales using InSAR; date active surface-rupturing faults using optically stimulated luminescence methods; date deformation of terraces and fans using optically stimulated luminescence, cosmogenic radionuclide, and radiocarbon methods; determine long term slip-rates using magnetostratigraphy and (U-Th)/He dates; and use seismic sections to constrain subsurface structure.

The role of active erosion in modulating deformation is still actively debated Whereas the conceptually attractive idea that focused erosion promotes localized and accelerated deformation is predicted by many numerical models very few unequivocal case studies exist that demonstrate such a linkage. This study in the Pamir-Tian Shan may provide unequivocal field evidence for a linkage between erosion and deformation because the region has many favorable attributes that should permit a clear assessment of the pattern and rate of deformation with respect to the river system. In addition to providing insight on the dynamics of mountain belts and assessing a popular tectonic geomorphology paradigm, paleoseismic analysis of several large active faults will improve understanding of the seismic hazards posed by these faults, some of which have produced deadly, recent earthquakes. Finally, the project will involve substantial collaboration with Chinese scientists, research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, and outreach to schools and museums.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the arid Tarim desert of far western China, the Pamir Range to the south and the Tian Shan mountains to the north  are rapidly converging with each other. Within this active collision zone, very active folds and faults accommodate crustal shortening between and within these ranges. Given the arid conditions with limited vegetation, the folds and faults are exceptionally well exposed and enable detailed analyses of how the shortening is being accommodated: what types of faults and folds are most important; how widely spaced are they: what trade-offs occur between folds and faults; what are the physical mechanisms by which the folds grow and faults slip; how rapidly has deformation migrated across the region; how steady or unsteady have rates of deformation been through time; and when, where, and why did "in-sequence" versus "out-of-sequence" deformation occur?

We determined the initiation of uplift for each fold using "magneto-stratigraphy" in which we reconstructed the sequence of reversals of the Earth's magnetic field that were recorded by the sedimentary rocks making up the folds. We then matched this pattern of reversals to a known time scale of magnetic reversals to determine the age of these strata and the initiation of uplift. We also used a technique relying on concentrations of subatomic particles (nuclides) that were produced by cosmic-ray bombardment when the sediments were at Earth's surface, but have been shielded from such bombardment since they were buried. The nuclide concentrations that we measure today are then used to date the last time that the sediment was exposed at Earth's surface, thereby adding another contraint on ages and rates of deformation. In addition, we have determined the ages of landform features, such as river terraces or planation surfaces, that have been subsequently deformed by faults or folds. With these ages, we determined rates of deformation  and, where we have multiple surfaces that have been dated, we can determine how rates have changed through time. With the approach, we have shown that, even though the locus of deformation has migrated through time toward the leading edge of each range, the rates of shortening have remained rather steady, such that modern rates and those from 100,000 years ago are nearly equal. Such data suggest that this region has been steadily accommodating a large amount of shortening for a long time.

Many folds reveal an exceptional abundance of flexural-slip faults: faults caused by differential slip between beds during folding. Their common occurrence has permitted new insights on how and when these faults form and how much of the overall shortening such localized faults accommodate.

Along this collisional corridor, elongate folds (>100 km long in places) are currently traversed by small, cross-cutting rivers in narrow canyons. Time control on the fold deformation indicates that the cores of the folds are uplifting at very rapid rates (~2-4 mm/yr or 2-4 km/million years). And yet,  the crests of many of these folds have been bevelled off by river erosion, such that as much as 95% of their uplifted mass has been eroded away, leaving nearly planar, gently dipping surfaces only a few tens of meters above the modern rivers. A provocative question is, "How did such extensive erosion occur by rivers in this arid setting; and what are the controls on the rates and extent of river erosion?" To address these questions, we conducted both field work and lab experiments. During the experiments, we "grew" a fold across a stream table and explored how the rate of uplift of the fold and the rate of lateral beveling by the river that crossed the fold were modulated by the ratio of (1) the sediment load being carried by the river to (2) the water flowing across  the stream table and the fold.  Our hypotheses were two-fold. First, we predicted that more rapidly uplifting folds would experience less lateral erosion (beveling) during any given time interval. Second, we hypothesized that higher sediment loads would cause the river channel to be less stable, such that the channel would jump (avulse) to new positions on either side of a pre-exisitng channel. Such avulsion was predicted to cause more extensive lateral erosion of the folds. These hypotheses were borne out by the stream-table experiments and were published in Nature Geoscience. Extensive field work was done to try to understand the timing of these beveling episodes, for example, were they synchronous across a region (likely driven by climate)? How long did they last? What did the underlying beveled surface look like? Given rates of rock uplift derived from dated river terraces, we were able to estimate how long it took to bevel these kilometers-wide surfaces. Surprisingly, we found that channels could bevel (erode) laterally more than 10 times faster than they would erode vertically, despite rather rapid rates of rock uplift.
